stream_context.summary: Kaze focuses on the new casino-in-space course (likely Course 15) and prepares a public demo while testing performance on real N64 hardware. Major tasks this stream were building a fading bridge, tuning lens-flare lighting, designing a warp platform with a dissolve animation, and adding low-gravity zones. He also brainstorms releasing a legally distinct, asset-swapped Steam version.

development_findings.summary: Course 15 now has a functional appearing bridge whose texture fades, darkens and vanishes; bug-fix required swapping texture formats and correcting a plus64 emulator issue.
development_findings.quote: Oh my God, that looks so good.

development_findings.summary: Implemented new warp platforms: Mario stands still, spins, scales down into the floor, is transported, and re-materialises; transparency was avoided by directly scaling the model matrix.
development_findings.quote: Applying transparency breaks all my components, so I just scale Mario into the ground.

development_findings.summary: Low-gravity volumes created via a custom collision type and a blue, scrolling cylinder; gravity toggle is one line (“low gravity’s on”).
development_findings.quote: It’s as simple as that—and now we can just put them wherever we want.

development_findings.summary: Lens-flare intensity bug traced to editing the wrong level index; fixing the correct entry allowed per-level intensity control.
development_findings.quote: I edited the wrong one. This is unbelievable.

development_findings.summary: Worst-case frame-rate on N64 hardware is ~22–25 FPS; typical views sit near 40 FPS and look fine at a 30 FPS cap.
development_findings.quote: There are Mario 64 levels that are worse than this.

development_findings.summary: Kaze plans to use the full 64 MB ROM space and is systematically replacing inefficient original Nintendo code for both speed and legal cleanliness.
development_findings.quote: Some of this code was literally twice as many cycles… I’m planning to replace it.

development_findings.summary: Demo build is almost ready; it will include Delfino as a secret level and probably this casino area, but no release date is set and it will not ship at Christmas to avoid clashing with Robot64’s release.
development_findings.quote: I don’t want to ruin his release.

development_findings.summary: Considering a commercial ‘Super Mario 32’ variant: 90 % of RTYI content, new protagonist, adjusted movement, and zero Nintendo assets, built with Recomp so it can ship on both Steam and real N64 hardware.
development_findings.quote: What if… we replace all the Nintendo IP with our own and sell it on Steam?

context_findings.summary: Kaze’s creative loop: outline desired moments, program needed actors, move pieces around until something feels fun, discard what isn’t, then polish.
context_findings.quote: Then I just start moving it around and see what’s fun and what isn’t.

context_findings.summary: He wants optional ultra-hard challenges, but worries they can frustrate average players and is looking for ways to hide them late-game.
context_findings.quote: I like putting super hard things in my games… but most players do encounter it and then they’re like, this sucks.

context_findings.summary: Strong dislike for small-talk greetings; reflects a direct, efficiency-focused worldview that shows in both code and social interaction.
context_findings.quote: Bro, that’s not a greeting, that’s a question.

context_findings.summary: Views community play-testing as ‘one trusted tester on repeat’ rather than public demos, though he admits public demos yield valuable analytics.
context_findings.quote: Personally, I send demos to one person and do that over and over.

biobak.summary: Reworking most of Kaze’s provisional textures, freeing Kaze to focus on code and layout.
biobak.quote: I shouldn’t spend so much time on textures… Biobak is reworking all my stuff anyway.

badub.summary: No direct appearance this stream, but Kaze solicited music suggestions and noted future OST needs, implying Badub will supply final score.

zeina.summary: Created the carpenter model and provided feedback on carpet and textures during stream.
zeina.quote: What do you think of this carpenter that Zeina made? Pretty cool, eh?

zeina.summary: Interacts as both spouse and animator; 47-month sub call-out shows long-term personal-professional overlap.
zeina.quote: Thank you for the 47 months, Zeina.

key_stories.title: Invisible Bridge Bug
key_stories.summary: A critical bridge in Course 15 appeared solid but was invisible in-game. Kaze traced the fault to texture-0 alpha reporting through the emulator and incorrect format flags.
key_stories.challenge: Bridge collision existed but geometry failed to render, confusing gameplay and level design.
key_stories.process: Tested in multiple emulators, experimented with RGBA-16, isolated that texture 0 alpha was mis-read, switched formats, and re-exported model.
key_stories.outcome: Bridge now materialises with a smooth fade and colour-shift effect, suitable for the demo.
key_stories.key_quote: This is what we wanted. Now it’s finally rendering.

key_stories.title: Warp Platform Conception
key_stories.summary: Kaze wanted a flashy teleport platform instead of the plain ‘fading warp’. He devised a scale-based dissolve animation to avoid transparency conflicts.
key_stories.challenge: Mario’s transparency flag breaks existing materials and adds CPU cost.
key_stories.process: Disabled transparency, wrote code to edit Mario’s transformation matrix, tuned frame timing and added under-lighting.
key_stories.outcome: Functional, visually striking warp pads ready for further placement.
key_stories.key_quote: Scaling the matrix is literally the easier way right now.

key_stories.title: Lens-Flare Intensity Mix-up
key_stories.summary: Excessively bright sun lens-flare overwhelmed visuals. Kaze thought intensity was ignored but realised he had modified the wrong level’s asset table.
key_stories.challenge: Changing the intensity value had no effect, leaving the flare blinding.
key_stories.process: Re-examined asset order, discovered levels were made in reverse, corrected index, retested.
key_stories.outcome: Flare brightness now tunable per level.
key_stories.key_quote: I edited the wrong one—because I made the levels in reverse order.
